Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this project is to develop polymerization chemistry for light-mediated control of the shape of a surface coating. This comprehensive study of a new class of monomers and polymer coatings will provide new insights and new capabilities in the field of nano- and micro-structures that change shape in response to light. We expect the development of this field of materials chemistry to enable the selective deposition of controlled-thickness films over many geometrically-complex actuation modes not currently accessible with traditional solution casting methods, overcoming a major technological hurdle associated with this exciting class of materials. The approach of this research will be to 1) use computational methods to evaluate the behavior of the proposed materials with experimental synthesis and characterization of the materials to rationally design a new class of light-responsive monomers, 2) evaluate speed and spatial control over coating formation, and 3) elucidate the governing principles of actuation of these coatings over complex nanoscale geometries.

If successful, this research will bridge the gap between two-dimensional actuatable materials and applications in devices as varied as artificial muscle motion, switchable surface adhesion, and directed fluid flow. Graduate students will be trained through the execution of this research. Undergraduate students will be trained in association with this project and an existing Research Experiences for Undergraduates program at the University of Kentucky. The computational effort will also integrate into ongoing outreach activities at Kentucky-based non-PhD granting institutions. The PIs will continue to attract and retain qualified undergraduate and graduate researchers from underrepresented minorities for the advancement of the proposed work. Finally, this work supports the development of an educational program in surface characterization and analysis for painting professionals at local and national automotive manufacturing facilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant focused on creating new molecules and materials that bend and move in response to light. The research team at the University of Kentucky established a new way of controlling chemical reactions using light to bend chemicals into a more active state. The team included experts in designing and analyzing molecules using computers, and these team members predicted how to combine light-active components with other chemistries to make the new chemical active in blue light and inactive in UV light. They determined a new class of molecule was possible, and the proposed type of molecule has never been made before. To determine how to best make these chemicals, the computational team determined which molecules structures were easiest to make, and other researchers on the team focused on making these target structures. While researching new concepts in light responsive polymerization, the team discovered an additional approach to making a new class of catalysts light responsive. Grubbs Catalyst is a powerful catalyst used to make polymers, drugs, and other high-value chemicals. This catalyst is not easily turned on or off. The project team discovered how to place a light-active group on this catalyst to make the catalyst inactive in UV light, but active in visible light. This allows chemists to carefully control these reactions to create better products. The research team also studied how to make light-responsive polymer coatings more stable. Many coatings made from these materials are easily damaged by solvent or wear. The team discovered a simple method of creating more chemical bonds in the polymer to make these coatings more stable and more useful.

This grant helped to fund the research of two graduate students in Chemical and Materials Engineering, and both graduate students went on to defend their dissertations. One student was rigorously trained in the computational design of molecules, and the other student was extensively trained in the making and analysis of new light-responsive molecules. This grant supported the training of three undergraduate students in modern scientific research methods, and two of these students were in underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines. This grant supported the training of a female postdoctoral scholar, where she developed skills in the mentorship of young researchers, interfacial engineering, and synthetic chemistry. This grant supported the training of US automotive engineers in next-generation polymer coatings and paints. The research findings have been published in peer-reviewed journals.
